commentBody:
I continue to be impressed by all the very young people making very good crossword puzzles! Nice job, Jackson!

I got I COULD EAT A HORSE very quickly, which set me up for a pleasant solve. Don't know that I've ever seen a TIARA with cameos on it, but I suppose you could do that. Overall, I thought this was a nice debut.
Great puzzle! Loved the long down entries.  I had almost nothing my first time through, but slowly filled in the east side, then the northwest, and finally the southwest. Nice job!
Nice puzzle, impressive debut.  Self-driving cars have been a constant presence in my neighborhood for years and I assure you they are vastly less dangerous than human drivers, Deb.
The clue for OBOES is 5D, not 9D as it says on the blog post, just an FYI. That had me scratching my head for a minute when I tried to cross it with TROLL.
The link to the completed crossword is to Thursday’s puzzle, not to today.

That was a nice, fresh challenge.

If you throw something off a ship, it’s JETSAM, not FLOTSAM. But we know what you meant, because Boston Harbor.
The clue for 53A confuses flotsam with jetsam

TROLL may have the clue of the year so far. 

ICOULDEATAHORSE was the gateway to the east, and SILVERBRACELET quickly followed. The west was a much harder nut to crack for me.

I liked the grid layout with the long verticals. Interestingly, the longer answers were easier to fill for me than many of the shorter ones.

16?! Debuting on a Friday (with a tough Friday)? Way to go, Jackson! You remind me of myself at 16. Well, with drive, focus, talent . . . but otherwise, a lot of similarities. A coda to yesterday’s puzzle. This morning, our local radio station had a short bit on “Stopping By Woods …,” as today (Thursday) is the 101st anniversary of its publication. It was Frost’s favorite of his poems. The backstory is poignant. Frost wrote the poem when he was struggling financially and feared he would not be able to buy Christmas presents for his children. An unsuccessful farmer, he rode his horse to town to try to sell some produce so he could purchase presents. He was unable to sell anything and rode back home in the snow. He stopped beside the neighboring woods and began to sob. His horse, Eunice, had the grace to let him have a good cry. Finally, Eunice jingled her bells and they continued their journey home. The story is related here: https://writersalmanac.publicradio.org/index.php%3Fdate=2012%252F03%252F07.html

Of all the benefits AI could initially provide humanity, as a commercial maiden voyage, why we chose SELFDRIVINGCARS, probably the most sophisticated and mortally dangerous enterprise in the raffle drum of ideas, will always baffle me. 

Then, again, let me tell you why Huey Lewis and the News’ “Fore!” is their most accomplished album…


cc: emu handler

For me, 10D might be a new record long entry got without any crosses.

Was otherwise also totally on Matz's wavelength as I cruised through this puzzle in half the time of yesterday's.

I'll feel much, much safer when all cars are SELF DRIVING and we wonder why we allowed distractable primates prone to road rage behind wheels for so long.
overall good puzzle with some quibbles. I think of oboes as low pitched not high, a tiara would be the last place I would expect to see a cameo and "onel" Is that like Law 101?

Wow, Jackson, a weighty entry for your college applications.  Sports? Great. Warbling? Cool. Both very nice, but not uncommon. However, debuting on the NY Times Crossword scene with a Friday puzzle? I can almost hear the CLAMORS of excitement in admissions offices far and wide!

The puzzle was lighthearted, but it wasn't easy, especially because I was determined to get "hungry as a HORSE" in there somehow and did a lot of entering and deleting before I finally accepted that it was time to move on.  I enjoyed the solve and I trust there won't be the kind of SHREWish grousing that greeted yesterday's debut.

Thank you, Mr. Matz, and best wishes for what promises to be a rich and fulfilling future.
Great debut puzzle, Jackson!  Especially loved the “troll” clue. My teenaged granddaughter gave me cool points for knowing this without her help. Thanks for a fun Friday!
Fun puzzle and wonderful debut, thank you! Echoing an earlier shout-out for TROLL. I had LIKE HERDING CATS at 31A before latching on to the CARS.

Pretty much a solid 0 on my first pass, gradually building up the Eastern edges until a large swath of the West lay before me, enshrouded in mystery. I could ELUCIDATE or EXPAND A BIT or tell you about FISHTAILING cars but those aren’t the answers you seek.

A water SHREW is new to me, as is Justicalism. I liked 16-Across (TROLL) and 21-Across (LESS).

Challenging for me but in retrospect there were some obvious things that might have helped the Western side of this puzzle; OBOES, DOES, ONEND, LIFT and CAT all seem familiar enough to be of service … maybe it was the clever phrasing of the clues that kept me off balance.

Cheers.
Just curious. Do any law schools call it “Civil Procedures” plural?

Congrats, Jackson!

I had the most trouble in the west. It didn't help that I thought that it was WHOOPIE CUSHION and I wanted CARE TO ELABORATE to be CARE TO ___ DETAILS. Of course, things did not fit for a while.

Anyway, the rest was okay, except that  TROLL was new to me.
Here’s an interview with Joel Fagliano on how he constructs the Mini crossword: https://tinyurl.com/yfukur32

I was starting to worry when my first two passes netted very few solid entries. Then the information from dusty corners of my brain started to creep forward.  

When I got TROLLS, the dopamine surge was great! Then my stomach growled, and I realized ICOULDEATAHORSE! It’s still the wee hours here in Portugal but I’m thinking I’d better wait until sunrise.

The grid began to fill, to my surprise.  THREE—— for Jonas Bros 15A. But TIARA felt like a stretch, and I’m with Deb (not DEB) on WHOOPEECUSHION. 

Amazing debut!

Congratulations on a fun debut, Mr. Matz! I zipped through the right half, but the left side was a bit more challenging. But even there, one answer would make another one apparent, and before long, I was done. That’s my favorite kind of crossword-solving experience. I especially enjoyed seeing CARE TO ELABORATE and I COULD EAT A HORSE. The latter reminds me of a song by the always amusing Greg Brown: https://tinyurl.com/yc4uux32’ I hope we’ll see you back here soon!

Great puzzle! This was a real challenge to get started, which is unusual for me. I finally got going in the SE corner; the clue at 40D for _ENS__ didn't really seem to work for sENSei, so I worked on the crosses before filling in that one. 😅

45A, tho. 😻
Congratulations Jackson, keep constructing! BISTRO was my last entry to solve the puzzle. I kept insisting on booths until I abandoned that and got BISTRO with all the crossings.

I stared and stared at WHOOxEECU with no clue how that would parse into words. The southwest corner sat there for the longest time with nothing but the end of CARE TO ELABORATE filled in. I'd just listened to a podcast about potato bugs/roly polies/pill bugs/wood lice (in which I learned that they're crustaceans, who knew?) but could not come up with ISOPOD without Google's help. Somehow that S broke WHOOPEE CUSHION open for me, and the last few entries came quickly.

Good puzzle! Congratulations to the constructor.
Stellar debut Jackson! I’m impressed. I got WHOOPIECUSHION and ICOULDEATAHORSE with virtually no crossings, so I guess our sense of humor connects even though I’m about 45 years your senior

Almost exactly what I am looking for from a Friday / Saturday puzzle.  I thought I was in a lot of trouble my first time through most of the clues... then I tried a few things in the SE corner and things came together... then it was a real struggle to branch out, but eventually, slowly, things filled in in fits and starts.  

In the end, I had to fix WAITONIT as the 4D and 5D weren't making any sense, but just getting the grid filled felt like an accomplishment.

Ultimately, I was in the middle of my usual time band for a Friday and it felt like a good challenge that I could chip away at without having Naticks or other unsolvable sections filled with proper nouns.  

5 stars, would solve again

A golden goose may make you go "Au," but a silver goose will lay an Ag.

(Now I'm in my element.)

That was a very unexciting way to clue THREESOME.

I still have not finished the puzzle as I'm writing this. I've had a good streak this week but it's over now - I've just had to enable autocheck and look up loads of proper names and trivia personally alien to me, and yet I am still mostly clueless in the western half of the puzzle. It's just one of those cases when you just don't click with the constructor I suppose, and these things happen, especially to non-native English speakers outside the US. I did remember DEB Haaland though, and I learned of her from these puzzles, so at least that's something 👍🏾. Also, I COULD EAT A HORSE was a rare case of a long entry I knew instantly. Still, not a personally enjoyable puzzle for me, this.

The eastern half of this puzzle came pretty easily to me, but the western side was TEEMing with difficulty. I didn’t know about isopods or water shrews, and I struggled for far too long trying to make sense of “SIEIN” as a synonym for “welcome”. But once I finally realized there might be another way to spell “WHOOPIE”, it all made sense. Nice debut.

One day in high school I was over at the house of a friend whose charming and sophisticated mother was not a native English speaker. 

She walked into the room and announced, with great aplomb, “Girls, I am so hungry I could eat a cow!”

In the moment, it felt like the funniest thing ever. Still a memory that makes me smile.

I’ve said this before in a different way: What I love about this community is that in response to a delightful, difficult and impressive debut puzzle, the comments include (in addition to well-deserved praise and encouragement for a young constructor)   the poignant backstory to an iconic Robert Frost poem alongside a bit of shade for choosing the Jonas brothers to clue “threesome”. (Thanks PM and Andrzej!)

I sometimes feel, dare I say it, that the comments are almost more fun than the puzzle. But the cart doesn’t come before the horse. Thank you Jackson!
As a chemist I have to object to APOLAR. Technically correct but almost no one uses that term. We prefer NONPOLAR. Rest of the puzzle was fun though.
The best puzzle of the week! That aha moment is what makes a puzzle worth doing, and this one had a few.
53A should be jetsam, not flotsam
Silver bracelet for 25 years of marriage?? 😩
Today I learned water shrews exist.
Still not fixed.
Also, I really thought the place to see a Cameo was going to be my PHONE.

Congratulations on a stellar debut, Jackson. I didn't have a whole lot on the first pass, and that's what makes a puzzle interesting for me. Excellent clue for TROLL, somewhat disappointing clue for THREESOME. Around my house, we sometimes say, "I could eat the hind leg of the lamb of god", but I knew that wouldn't fit in 10 D. The Acoustic Motorbike (Luka Bloom) https://youtu.be/Y1yFHAugbnM?si=a8bt0AtrBH-P3xm1 Of course we would never do such a thing.
Dear Deb, OBOES is 5D, not 9D.
A WHOOPEE CUSHION is a JOKE that goes under your BUTT. (It makes a noise when you sit down.) Nice clue. And fun puzzle!

Nice puzzle and a typical long Friday workout for me. In the end I got stuck in the very middle and had to go into my... 'run the alphabet' mode on a couple of squares. That's what finally got me to JINX, which was never going to dawn on me from the clue. That's all on me. 

And... 16 years old! Wow! just Wow. I have a feeling that Jackson Matz is going to become a very familiar name around here. 

And... answer history search today led to a very puzzling result, though something I've kind of come across before. Today I'm going to put that in a separate comment rather than a reply. 

..

Loved it! 🧩💖

Somewhat slow for me for a Friday but it had a perfect amount of friction for me. Slow but never felt helpless, and when I figured things out I was always pleased at the right answer rather than disappointed. Some interesting echoes throughout, too. I wanted the chemistry term to be ISO-something and then that popped up in ISOPOD. SELFDRIVINGCARS crossing ROAD and GTOS. ARISE on the top and -END and IMTHERE on the bottom. And as a high school teacher and current parent of teens I especially applaud you for your dedication and drive to put this puzzle together and get it to the attention of the New York Times! Well done!

As threatened below: 

Answer history search today was for 33d. Went and looked up GTO and GTOS. And... I've come across things like this before but NEVER to this extent. Anyway...

GTOS has been an answer 58 times in the Shortz era, and... NEVER in a pre-Shortz puzzle. 

And... GTO - 119 times in the Shortz era and... ONCE in a pre-Shortz puzzle (1984). And the GTO car debuted in 1964. 

It's a very friendly piece of fill. I can only assume that here has to have been some kind of change in standards there for certain types of answers, but I just can't imagine what it might be or... why.

Anyone have any thoughts on this?

...

A typical difficult Friday solve for me and I loved the long vertical spanners ( and near spanners).  It was especially fun to find out that we have a new young constructor making a very impressive debut puzzle.  

I’ve been having extreme difficulty with posting a comment for quite a few days now as my screen goes crazy, asks for password and email address and other things I can’t remember right now.  I’ve asked for help, but that advice has been too complicated to help at all.
Counter clockwise solve from bottom center as I had crickets on first pass.  Probably should not attempt something as clever as this in the middle of the night.  Amazing debut.

Wonderful puzzle, I really enjoyed the "Needle on a thread" clue. Unfortunately didn't know the other definition of cameo before today (or at least that knowledge was buried deep), and the west slowed me down considerably, so my time was pretty poor. 

Made a lovely train journey from Bath to Southampton even more enjoyable.
Very solid puzzle that’s a perfect Friday. A fair challenge and an excellent debut for the constructor.

Welcome Jackson Matz! Thank you for a fun Friday fill. I discovered a few spanners early in the solve, but that didn’t help my overall completion time. However my time was 6 minutes faster than my slow average for Friday. 

TGIF

Lots of promise here from this new voice, this 16-year-old constructor.  Putting together a grid with three spanners (with one intersecting the other two) plus two 14s, without ugliness (that is, a spate of junky answers) – as Jackson has done – is puzzle-making acumen no matter what the age.

Coming up with memorable clues that have never been used before, that’s a talent that marks a constructor as special.  [Needle on a thread?] for TROLL is just such a clue.

Building in bite fairly in a themeless is an art, and this puzzle is not encumbered by the arcane or overly stretchy clues, yet, for me at least, it has areas that made me work, the kind of work my brain finds delicious.

So, the seeds are here for glimmering grids to come, building on what for me today was a splendid outing.  Thank you for that, Jackson, and congratulations on your Times debut!
Flotsam refers to floating objects that accidentally fall off a boat.  The tea chests in the water at the Boston Tea Party were deliberately thrown overboard, and would therefore be jetsam.

In 22A, what is the second part of the clue referring to?  I get the first part (that POT is a synonym for weed, or “herb”), but I’m having trouble understanding the “or a lead-in to herb” part of the clue.
Civil Procedure, not Civil Procedures. There's no S at the end.

I really liked some of the clever cluing such as “needle on a thread?”
The clue “balanced molecule” has be used several times before, so I knew the answer. However, as a chemist and chemistry teacher, I have not encountered this word in describing molecules. The better word is nonpolar. Perhaps, a different clue can be used in the future?

Yowza, Mr. Matz! The whole west half of the puzzle was a perfect example of "close the PC--walk away--do something else (balance the checkbook)--reopen the PC--complete the puzzle." 

But MAUVE sent me down a lovely rabbit-hole. As a color term, "Mauve" doesn't predate the late 18th c., with the accidental synthesis of the first aniline dye by William Henry Perkins in 1859. That much I knew. What I was surprised to discover was that the chemical structure of mauveine (as it's known today--a complex of at least 12 molecules) was not fully determined until 1994! Is mauveine apolar? Not sure . . . any chemists out there welcome to fill me in.

Cameo-studded tiaras, silver bracelets on mauve (satin gloves) bespeak a fin-de-siecle opulence unexpected from a 16-year-old. 

I look forward to more.

Great workout!  Amazing debut!  I found this challenging but fun—perfect for a Friday. 
Bravo, Jackson!
This was fun and challenging but totally approachable. After working through it counter clockwise it started to solve itself.
spellcheck caught me.  the man in the photo is likely sewing a man's thobe, not those.

Hokey smoke, Bullwinkle! That was tough. The wee pup BB jangles the silver bracelet on her collar in wonderment at the notion of cameos on a tiara, needle on a thread, and such like divergations as excellent examples of difficulty for difficulty's sake without much element of fun along the way. It must be said that she is put off by the notion of anyone eating a horse, as one of her closest companions is Bob, the gelding.

Perhaps she just feels dyspeptic this morning and should keep her thoughts to herself.

In any event, she thanks you for the work out, and sends her best regards.

This was a tough one - maybe because I have approximately 60 years on the setter (there's a scary thought) I am not in his wheelhouse or he is not in mine or whatever - I have never understood that expression.

Regardless - 16A Needle on a thread? was worth the price of admission.
23A APOLAR is not used in chemistry. It's either nonpolar or polar. But not apolar.

WHOOP de doo!  WOOF!  WOWzer-dowzer...
The entire left side of this puzzle really gave me fits.  I had just enough filled in to throw me for a loop.
Add that I put GEARS at the endof 31A (as in, monkey wrench in the...) and was torn between TAX and MAX (out).....plus at one point I took out ELABORATE...  well, you get the idea.  A struggle!

It's enough to UNsettle ONE'S NERVEs...

The one clue/entry I still don't really 'get' is the first half of the clue for POT.  POTherb is a thing.  But "Herb"= POT?  UNUH.

Impressive debut, Mr. Matz.  (This will look good on your college applications, eh?)   But surely there are some ISOPODs out there who need squashing--no need to practice on your elders!

Very hard for me, but I finished it with no cheats.  Two early wrong answers didn't help.  I had baTOn before ROTOR-- I guess you "twirl" a baton rather than "whirl" it, but I didn't think of that.  And, for reasons I can't explain, I had TD toSS before TD PASS.

When tOT didn't seem like a very good answer to the whole "Herb" thing, I finally changed my TD TOSS answer and got POT.  I think I have struck out on every single pot-based clue that has ever appeared in the NYTXW.  I don't smoke the stuff, I can't stand the stench of the stuff, and I certainly don't know the many nicknames for the stuff.  In contrast, liquor has a lot of nicknames too, but I know them all. 

DEET before DCON.  I always make that mistake.

What does BALLER mean?  I don't even know what sport we're playing.  Do you?

WHOOPIE CUSHION was pretty clever and it was my last long entry in.  I saw the ?USH and, based on "butt", I wanted TUSH.  Can you blame me?

I never felt I was on the same wave length as this constructor.  Sometimes you do, sometimes you don't.  BUB for "chap".  TOWARD for "nearing".  RURAL as the description of a home and not for the place the home is situated.  Nothing was actually wrong, mind you, but some of this didn't feel quite...right.  Off-kilter enough to make this a tough solve for me.

Thanks Jackson! That was fun to solve and a most impressive debut. I loved the construction and the clueing. Though I have more than half a century on you this was on my wavelength. Best wishes on all your many endeavors.

Good Friday puzzle - just enough to keep me scratching my head. Loved 13D. re the NONPOLAR/POLAR/APOLAR comments, chromatography is often done on an apolar support using polar or nonpolar solvents. 
Cue the emus.

Part of the fun of the Friday/ Saturday puzzle is figuring out the long answers so how about instead of revealing those as “tricky clues “ you instead reveal more of the crossers? Or if you are going to reveal them, force us to click an additional hyperlink, as used in the Frost poem retelling. Thanks!
The word OBOE is derived from the French HAUTE BOIS which translates to HIGH WOOD, and wood instruments are sometimes called "winds"...
Gosford park was directed by Julian Fellowes. It was written by Robert Altman

I imagine there are some proud teachers in the staff room today - with nods to algebra, biology, chemistry, social studies, and literature. Here’s to the educators who provide fuel for bright minds like Jackson Matz!!

Kudos to Jackson Matz!  Very enjoyable solve.

Tough. Baffling. Perplexing. But slooowly, my brain caught up to Jackson's.  Catchy clues. Clever language.  Memorable debut.

I raise my coffee cup to our young puzzler. More please!

Oh boy, another excellent, crunchy debut from a teenager. 

Mr. Matz is clearly already not a hedgehog, but a fox, who knows many things.

Along with producing delightful puzzles, Mr. Matz and his fellow young constructors give me hope for the future. It takes flexibility, wit, intelligence and knowledge to make a puzzle like this one. Those are also traits that we desperately need now and will need in the future to counteract and correct the damage done to our nation and our environment by destructive and ignorant policies, and to overcome the tide of the witless, which I hope has already passed its high point.

Thanks, Mr. Matz!

Great debut, Mr. Matz! 
Quite challenging, but lots of fun. Even though I am more than 50 years older, your puzzle was still in my wheelhouse. 
Wishing you success in all your future endeavors and hope to meet you in this space again.

Great debut and a nice upgrade from yesterday's debacle.  (Yeah, still ticked off that puzzle made it to publication.)

Loved the cluing for 20A POT and 16A TROLL.  As usual, my weakness was spelling.  How do you spell CUSHION.  Is it cussion, cuscion...SHREW saved me.

Outstanding debut puzzle by a brilliant young constructor.

I didn't have a problem with the "stretch" on the whoopee cushion clue, since it's the butt that makes the joke.

Congrats Mr. Matz!

March 8 crossword - 53 across. As the teachests were thrown into the harbor, surely they are “jetsam” as opposed to “flotsam” - the latter being items accidentally or unknowingly deposited in the sea?

Wow. Such an impressive grid from so young a brain. I can only bow down in respect. Tough enough to need to engage the little grey cells but not impossible. My favourite kind.

Excuse me now while I go and stick this under DH’s nose. Where was my SILVER BRACELET?? We hit 40 years this year. I’d better get a ruby the size of a duck egg or there’ll be trouble. (Doesn’t hold breath).

After breezing through yesterday's puzzle, I was way over average on this one. But I enjoyed them both. Very satisfactory to keep plugging away. No lookups, though sorely tempted a couple of times.  What was that Argentinian theory? Just anothe excuse for authoritarianism or a bit more? And did the inventor believe in it himself? Sort of like the questions now about You-know-who.
  TIL that if I take up bicycling again I'll need to watch out for self-driving cars. I am not as sanguine as one of the commenters that the technology will evolve. (They can't do parking  lots now either.) At least Boston is working on more bike-only lanes. Maybe in 30 years it'll be as good as China. (Yeah, I know, unfair comparison.)

Quite the connector between Thursday and Friday puzzle. 

That restless HORSE must have really annoyed the rider. now he wants to eat it…




CARE TO ELABORATE?

Fun puzzle, Loved whoopee cushion as "butt of a joke" but one slight correction (which perhaps another solver has already noted). 

As the Boston tea party involve tax protesting Bostonians throwing tea chests into the harbor, it was not flotsam but rather jetsam.
Too tough for me today. I solved the whole right side of the puzzle, but struck out almost completely on the left side!

NOBODY uses the word APOLAR in chemistry. The correct term is "non-polar" and is extremely rare, seen only in diatomic homogeneous molecules (e.g. H2, O2 etc) or molecules of very high symmetry such as benzene.
MASTER took me super long I thought of every other meaning before that
Jetsam, not flotsam. And the cluing was weirdly inconsistent. Doubt many were able to find a vibe with this one.
those are not winds. They are reeds, or double reeds.
Flotsam are items not intentionally thrown off a ship. Jetsam would be the correct term for the clue in this puzzle.

I got through the whole right side and then had to wait a bit before I got anything on the left side.  Then I had to wait a bit again in the spot where I had WAITonIT (even though it bothered me that the word "it" was also in the clue).  Kind of meta that I had to wait a bit before I got WAITABIT.  A challenging puzzle for sure, though my time was 12% less than my average.  A fine debut.

Good one, and impressive debut.
I was convinced that 15D (Throw for six...) had something to do with dice/craps, of which I know nothing. And I knew that Australians call kangaroos joeys*, so I convinced myself that TjPASS was gambling slang. After flyspecking the entire puzzle I went back and stared at that spot really hard, and the penny finally dropped. Dohs.

*of course, after-the-solve research taught me a joey is 
"a baby animal. especially : a baby kangaroo."

Fantastic puzzle. 16? Wow. 

Needle on a thread was brilliant. 

I don’t understand the wordle clue. Is it because if you get today’s wrong you break a streak?

For the life of me couldn't figure out how 54A fit the clue. Then I moved the space to the left. Doh!

I loved this puzzle! Challenging yet doable for me, and lots of fun clues.

Loved this! I had at least 6 different “ahaaaaa” moments, which punctuated a quiet morning and made my husband laugh. 

Had already crowned it one of my favorite puzzles of late and then discovered that this was a debut for a teen constructor! Very impressed.

Thank you Mr. Matz!
Hard but fair. Great debut, Jackson.

CARE TO ELucidATE?
It took a few rounds to get that southwest corner whipped into shape. but I got there. Can I have my TIARA now?

Good, crunchy puzzle, Jackson, thanks.


I went back to yesterday's column, saw that there's over 480 comments. Even though there were no rebuses, no app malfunctions, no tricks beyond a paraphrased poem. That seems like a Thursday number of comments, so I guess the puzzle proved itself Thursday-worthy.
Bravo to Jackson for such a fun and challenging debut (and at such a young age on top of it). Impressive 👏🏾👏🏾👏🏾

TIL that Swedish royalty are seen now and then wearing a famous cameo-adorned TIARA (well, famous as tiaras go), though the Bernadotte Cameo Tiara seems to be well-known (again, well-known for a tiara!) in part because of its unique design features. Maybe that's the "one" tiara the clue at 49A was referencing?

Great puzzle, but arrgh!  I had RUB for 38A (Chap) instead of BUB, turning BISTRO to RISTRO, (which I thought might be a neologism I hadn't heard for a restobar or what have you).  I just wasn't able to see my mistake in the end, and had to Reveal.  :(
Oh, I also thought that 13D (Butt of a joke?) was going to have something to do with mooning/pressed ham. The west and southwest really slowed me down!

Wow, delightfully hard puzz today. This was one of those that made me say to myself "Oh this one is too hard I won't bother" But then I came back to it in the afternoon, and, with a little luck, and a little pluck, I got my jazzy leitmotif after an hour and 3 minutes or so!

A really tough puzzle for me, but part of that might be because of some questionable clues which didn't quite add up. For example practice squad as the clue to doctors. Really? Sure, doctors practice medicine, but lawyers also practice the law, and violinists practice the violin, etc. Some of the best clues are right on the edge. Some of these were over the edge.
an abaya is a woman's garment and is black.  i believe the gentleman in the photo is sewing a man's those.
Loved this one. THREESOME lol.
If I'm not mistaken, an Abaya is a women's garment; men wear dishdishas.
brilliant tough and on point.... good for the brain thank you!
Terrific workout!

Great puzzle! My experience seems different from many others as I completed the entire left side plus selfdrivingcars but then wanted 22D to be step which didn't fit with 31A. Then the long verticals on the right side came in.  Really nice cluing except I don't know "jinx".
Great Friday puzzle; loved the longer entries (& their clues) in particular. Congrats, Mr. Matz!
Can someone explain to me what the answer to 36 across means?

The time has come.

I'd doing crossword puzzles written by people younger than my back pain.

Sigh.

"Non-polar" vs. "apolar"

"floatsam" vs. "jetsam"

oboes being "winds" vs. "reeds"

They ought to call this forum "The Pedants' Corner"

Going to have to admit to this group that much of the West, especially SW, stumped me for ages. I couldn’t see “WHOOPEE CUSHION” for the life of me (kept wanting a joke that starts with “WHO” then the vowels would crush me afterwards). 

I finally let myself Google judicialism, which gave me PERON, which gave me a cross, and suddenly everything clicked. Fun puzzle! Hard puzzle!
If this level of difficulty is a NYT debut at 16 without excessive references to typical teen cultural interests, I have no trouble calling it the work of a prodigy.
It was a challenge and I enjoyed it. Congratulations! You are a star.
Can someone explain what a pot herb is? I am afraid to google it as i am on a shared computer in the public library

Very nice debut, Jackson.  The entire west coast was the last to fall for me.  I really liked the adjacent long verticals.  However, I let myself get fixated on the butt of the joke having something to do with an exploding cigar. It took me awhile to unthink that.

Way to go, Jackson! I enjoy Friday puzzles like this one, when they are quite tricky and require me to take breaks and return with a different mindset throughout the day. I was definitely started out on your wavelength filling in 1D with no crosses, but your clever clues provided plenty of aha moments, especially needle on a thread? and throw for six? Looking forward to your next one!

Terrific puzzle. Like many others, I breezed through the east on the back of I COULD EAT A HORSE and SILVER BRACELET, and i caught on to the wonderful SELF-DRIVING CARS soon after. The west, however, took much longer — to the point where I thought this puzzle might be the backbreaker that would force me to sneak a peek at Google. (Okay, that was maybe a bit premature because I was still only 15 minutes at that point — but I had that *feeling* like I might never get another answer.

And then, as happens with the most satisfyingly challenging puzzles, I got a toehold here and there — TEEM led to STEM, I remembered that there were three Jonas Brothers rather than two, I stopped thinking dice and saw TD PASS, and the rest started to fall into place. 

Then I read the comments and saw that Jackson is 16, and — wow.

Great debut, Jackson. I look forward to many more!
For today, you can KMA.

So happy to see the reappearance of OBOEs.
But has my favorite instrument replaced OTOEs?  It’s been a while since the last sighting of the midwestern First People!
Wow, Jackson, awesome debut. Loved the long vertical fill. Eager for your next puzzle, and good luck on the SAT/ACT, though something tells me you won't need any luck.
Awful puzzle. Not enjoyable!

My jaw dropped when I saw the constructor's age. Well done, Mr Matz. Well done. 

I will admit there were a couple clues here that I solved by crosses and still didn't get - I assume TDPASS is something from either American slang or sports? (Or both?) - and some factoids that I had to Google to check, which made the solve just a little bit less satisfying, but overall this was a nice Friday. I did love those long spanners. And "needle on a thread" made me chuckle.

I will grudgingly concede that this was a good puzzle, even though I had to resort to Google for a lot of the west side.  There were many answers that I would never have gotten no matter how many times I walked away and came back.  I found this much harder than most Saturday and Sunday puzzles.  
And I agree with the whoopee cushion complaints. The clue doesn’t quite match the answer, even with the ‘?’

Tough but fun. 
I enjoyed the “aha” moments.
Still don’t get “Jinx”. Maybe it’s because I’m older….
Well done!
Particularly difficult Friday for me. I’ll take it up with the editors if tomorrow’s is easier.

Took more than 2x my average time for a Friday. Not a fan of the clues. Not fun, just difficult and vague. I wonder how many were made by looking for the biggest stretches of synonyms in the thesaurus.

A debut? By a 16-year old? Really? What a satisfying solve!... slowly filling in crosses to eventually figure out the mysteries of the long fill-- WHOOPEE CUSHION, one of my last finds. I did resort to research on Salome to get unstuck. Such interesting clues-- loved the LIES quote. One of those rare puzzles for me, not requiring any fly specking-- filled in TAX, then JINX, and was surprised and delighted by the tiny tune of triumph. I would say this puzzle was triumph for you, Jackson. (I will be sure to remember your first name-- an unusual one, which you share with my grandfather). Many congratulations, Jackson, on your stellar debut.
That was tricky.  The nexus of TDPASS, SEEIN, and APOLAR had me hung up for a very long time.  I was down to trying random letters and was a bit startled when it played the solved tune.

If there's a rookie of the year award in puzzle construction then Mr. Matz should definitely be in contention. This was a fun, challenging solve made extra special by the youth of the constructor.

Congratulations!
Not to be the pedantic chemist here (yet alas, I will be) but *nobody* uses apolar for molecular polarity. It’s always nonpolar.
very stoked that i beat my average w zero look-ups! this was a good one. congrats, Jackson!

Because SELF DRIVING CARS do not text or make phone calls while they are driving.  

Because SELF DRIVING CARS never drive drunk.

Because SELF DRIVING CARS never drive stoned.

Because SELF DRIVING CARS never drive tired or sleepy.

Because SELF DRIVING CARS don't suffer from road rage.


Because human drivers do all of the above things.



Because SELF DRIVING CARS learn from their mistakes.

Because a lot of human drivers do not.


Because SELF DRIVING CARS can work when all their occupants are sleeping.

Because SELF DRIVING CARS (and trucks) can work when there are no occupants.


Any questions?

@Steve L self driving cars do not respond correctly to bicycles. I have had 3 very close calls where SDC's ignored my presence, and one almost hit me.   This is over the last 5 years.  And none of those times did the driver stop to see if I was OK.  
In the save time, I've only had 2 close calls with human drivers.  But they were driving Mercedes. And they didn't stop either.

@Asher A ONE L is a first-year law student. "High winds" has been used three times to clue OBOES; "High wind" has been used five times to clue OBOE. Its name comes from the French "hautbois", literally meaning "high wood(wind)". Here's a page full of TIARAS with cameos: https://tinyurl.com/5696ss8b

@Asher 

“ONE L” is a 1977 book by Scott Turow about his first year at Harvard law school.  Despite some skepticism expressed  in these comments when ONE L has appeared as an entry, from my own experience, I can report that the term has continued to be used to refer to first year law students.

@Steve L I had the same thought as Asher about the cameos. That link is interesting - a lot of the images seem to be of the same tiara, a Swedish royal family thing. It still seems like a strange place for a cameo but who am I to argue? Here's an article with more information on that particular tiara, which originally came from Empress Josephine of France (Napoleon's wife). https://www.thecourtjeweller.com/2021/02/the-stories-of-swedens-romantic-cameo.html
@Figgsie Not a law student past or present, but I wonder if you might refer to the class with an S in a sentence like: "I've gotta run or I'll be late to Civil Procedures".

@Figgsie 

I have no idea about the US, but in Poland and Polish, while the whole subject at law school may be called 'Civil procedure,' and we have a Civil Procedure Code (how I hated learning that, sweet baby Jesus), the law actually regulates many specific types of civil procedures: there is (and I'm roughly translating this from Polish) family cases procedure, consumer cases procedure, business cases procedure, etc.

There are a range of tools that a remote helper, such as your son, could use to access your computer to check it out.  One is called Teamviewer which, after setting up the account and software, would allow him to take a look at what is going on.  Plenty of other applications out there as well.  Microsoft Windows had a tool called Remote Assistant.  I've been out of the IT game for some time so I'm not sure what is current but I know that Teamviewer works well.

@C Right — and I assumed the “?” made it clear that we weren’t looking for the actual butt of joke, as the phrase is used. Regardless, my juvenile mind went straight to whoopee cushion for the clue! :)

@Terence Elliott Flotsam floats - the words have similar etymologies.  Jetsam is almost a back formation from 'jettison,' and mariners in trouble usually jettison heavy - i.e. non floating - cargo.  'Jettison' is from the Latin 'jactare' - to throw, seen also in eject, conjecture etc.  So while the tea chests were definitely jettisoned, I suspect they floated.

pot·​herb ˈpät-ˌərb  -ˌhərb
: a usually leafy herb that is cooked for use as greens
also : one (such as mint) used to season food

What Vaer says...

...but thanks for explaining "Herb" as POT.  My mind just never goes there.  I was 'of that generation'--a Baby Boomer--but on the leading edge, having been born in 1947.  
When our daughter was born, we were referred to as "elderly first-time parents"....but as the rest of us Boomers delayed parenthood (finishing our educations, establishing careers) it came to be much more the norm.  Now when I say the kids were born when I was 33 and 36, it's not unusual at all.  
....and I guess I "missed out" when it came to the drugs (if that was missing out.)  A teacher's salary didn't run to extras.

@Robert Kern The two terms apolar and non-polar are used interchangeably and both refer to molecules without a dipole moment.  50 years of persuading various employers that I am just the chap they need in their lab, qualify me to answer this question.  I think apolar is a little more common on the other side of the Atlantic than in the US, but I have only anecdotal evidence for that.

@John - Technically, I think they are neither. But since this is a crossword, I think either can be considered a valid answer to this clue, which is not supposed to be a definition, but a hint. 

Jetsam is technically stuff thrown overboard a sinking ship to lighten it. The TEA CHESTs were not that. But they also were not floating *wreckage*. 

I do agree that "jetsam" in many ways would be a better answer, for the reason you state, but I conclude that either is valid. 

YMMV.

@John et al.
All this kerfuffle about Flotsam vs. Jetsam (weren't those characters in Beatrix Potter?) has sent me down a delightful rabbit-hole concerning the Boston Tea Party: in today's value, some $1.7M worth of tea became either flotsam or jetsam. 

"But was it organic?" asks my Brother-in-Law, who will drink no other.

And according to Wikipedia: "The American Antiquarian Society holds in its collection a vial of actual tea-infused harbor water from 1773."

Talk about historical forethought!

@frankie - I'm a marine biologist whose research interests are primarily in biochemical adaptations. 

As Francis, an actual chemist, has pointed out, APOLAR is not common -- I have run into it mostly in very old papers and textbooks. But nonpolar is, as Francis has stated, a very, very common term, especially in biochemistry. Like most crossword clues, this one is a hint -- and although I doubt my definition of the word would include the word "balanced," I know what the writer meant, and the answer was, for me a pretty easy get.
@Leah Agree!  I had MASTEn thinking maybe it was some kind of sailing term.

@ice9 Oboes are for sure double reeds, but they also are woodwinds. An oboe is a member of a woodwind quintet, for example, and, all instruments that require breath are winds - different from strings and percussion.

@Scott 

Loved the "factory reset"!

It reminded me of something my mom used to say.
Once my siblings and I hit the age of 18 and had minor health quibbles (headaches, cavities, etc.), 
she made it clear that we were to take care of it ourselves. 
And how did she do that?
Simple. 
If we shared with her our complaints, she'd say "Sorry, honey. The factory's been closed for over a decade and the warranty has expired." :-)

@Aethon I don't think age has anything to do with it. The jinx ritual has been around for at least 50 years. Psychological study from 1973: https://psycnet.apa.org/record/1974-25013-001.
@Tom Bantle I'm old, too, but I'll take your word for it that this is not a new thing. I've never heard it/heard of it until just now, though.
@Gil Hivens I interpreted this as “Folks I’d find at a (medical) practice.” So “practice” as a noun, not a verb.
@Nick S It’s when you and someone else say the same thing at the same time. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinx_(game)

@Caro Yes and there are a variety of rituals to avert or at least acknowledge the jinx. I grew up on "Jinx you owe me a chocolate malt!" (Not that any ever were offered.) In the Donna Andrews Meg Lanslow mystery series (set in the Virginia piedmont), one person is supposed to ask "What goes up the chimney? " and the other to answer "Smoke". 
   Any other jinx-averters out there?

@Kyle When I was growing up (I'm in my 40s), it was a common game to attempt to be the first to say "jinx"if you and another person said something identical at the same time. Then the person who got "jinxed" wasn't allowed to speak again until the person who said it first "unjinx"ed them. An alternate game for the same situation was to say "you owe me a Coke," although I'm still waiting to collect on a number of those.

Dear Deb,

After deliberation, I think the whoopee cushion could be considered to play the roll of the artificial butt of the target of the joke. Therefore, butt of the joke.

A bit convoluted, but I think it works!
A fun solve, and agreed so great young folks are constructing. Think 13D works, though. The article was the key for me — “Butt of A joke,” as though a whoopee cushion is a “butt-focused” joke LOL.

A fantastic debut—full of sly humor and clues that celebrate idioms and have multiple possibilities for answers. I relish simple clues like "Get down" which fill my mind with everything from alighting to dancing to ducks...then lead to something completely different. I'm old enough to be relieved there were no references to rappers or the Marvel Universe, but am patting myself on the back for guessing TROLL nearly off the bat. 

As an oldie to a newbie, all I can say is, You're in the groove, Jackson.

Congrats on the debut! A fine Friday puzzle. The eastern half of the grid fell easily, but the western half made me work. Not familiar with ISOPOD, but it made some sense. Thinking liquidITY rather than liquidATE certainly slowed me down. 

Alternate clue for 53A: Blessed is the man whom thou chastenest, O Lord , and -------- him out of thy law (Psalm 94 KJV)

Liked ICOULDEATAHORSE, and was very grateful that this horse was not restless and no one uttered GIDDYUP today.

Like others, the SW corner gave me the most trouble. WHOOPIE CUSHION was easy enough, but for some reason my brain wanted 1D to be CARE TO ELUCIDATE and it wouldn't let go. It didn't help that ELUCIDATE  and ELABORATE are the same length and both end in ATE. Further confusing things, 54A really should be NO END, not ON END (which means something entirely different). It finally dawned on me that a wood louse is an ISOPOD, and that you might indeed put cameos in a TIARA. I gave myself a dope slap and got rid of ELUCIDATE.

All in all, it's a fine puzzle with some clever clues.
Deb:  Oboe comes from the French hautbois, or “high wood”, so the clue works and is very clever!

What a terrific debut for young Mr. Matz! I was a a little surprised to find that out after finishing this delightful and challenging grid. It was full of charm, and at times made me feel very smart—when one of those long grid spanners popped into my head and turned out to be right, and when I filled in TROLL and it turned out to be right too. TIL there is such an animal as a water SHREW, and that some TIARAs contain cameos. I look forward to more puzzles from this talented young man.
Thanks, Deb. I tried on another device & i it worked. What a great first effort!
Wow!  Kudos, Jackson Matz. Well done!
Nitpicky note: TEACHEST wouldn’t be flotsam, but jetsam, having been tossed overboard.

Yesterday, I had a catastrophic, cruciverbal conniption when discovering news of Will’s early February medical event; bummer. Purporting strong hope for a speedy recovery, I am anticipating a hearty, bounce back rehab; get well soon. The WP puzzlers form a worldwide support system that is in the blue penciler’s corner. This is a LeAnn RIMES ballad, “Blue,” https://youtu.be/GozdIQx1Wow?si=WgxU4YguQXqpDX1X Congrats to you and your team Jackson. You’re one SHREWd CAT. Courageous of you, jumping right into the deep end of WP pool. With Well Wishes For Will, Bru
ISOPOD got me! I had RUB for “chap” (made enough sense at the time) and RESTRO for the casual dining place, which I assumed was slang I hadn’t heard before. But otherwise a joy!

Congrats to the new constructor, great challenging puzzle! One question, if someone can help me understand EVE answer: Clue was Good name for last-minute planner? Is it because they work on it the night before it's due? Not sure about that one.

This was straight up hard. Most difficult Friday in a LONG time—6 months, maybe more! Great long clues and misdirects. I got the southeast corner, then took way longer for the northwest corner, and the rest came together pretty slowly.

@Tim G  Jetsam, cp jettison, is anything thrown off a ship. Flotsam is anything that floats off a sinking ship. At least, that’s my understanding of the relevant maritime law, something not in ONEL.


Emus don’t sail so have no née to make this distinction.

@Ern It’s another example of the editors not caring about accuracy.

Stick around. It happens often.
The TEA CHESTs in question were neither flotsam nor jetsam by maritime law or custom. By crossword practice, they could be either. https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/flotsam-jetsam.html

@frankie 

I am a chemist.  I don't specifically recall ever using APOLAR, but if I did use it I would expect an intelligent person to understand it.  Anyone with a knowledge of how English works is going to recognize that non-polar and apolar are going to be the same things.

Crosswords are not supposed to be air tight.  They are exercises in fuzzy logic.

And apolar compounds are NOT extremely rare.  Many of the simple compounds are apolar.  Methane.  Carbon tetrachloride.   Carbon dioxide.  You mentioned benzene.  But also para-xylene, hydroquinone, trinitro toluene (TNT).

Beyond those from simple symmetry, almost all hydrocarbons are considered to be non-polar because the C-H bond is not very polar, and there is enough symmetry to wipe out any meaningful amount of polarity.
